mushrooms.name: Blushing Rosette
mushrooms.description: A beautiful, wide-pored annual polypore with a varied appearance. Its most common form is the rosette form, but it has many different irregular forms, including an upside-down, hemispherical form too.
mushrooms.fruitingBody:
Often forms irregular fruit bodies, the below mentioned description describes the regular, rosette form of the species.
Cap 5-20 cm across, nearly flat, roundish to rosette-like, turns irregularly lobe with age; nearby fruit bodies often fused together. Its upper, sterile surface is initially white to off-white, then pink to reddish brown; smooth to slightly hairy (tomentose). Margin thin and paler than the rest of the upper surface, bruising reddish brown when handled or damaged.
Stem 4-7 cm long and 2-3 cm thick, tapering towards the base, often deeply 'rooting'.
mushrooms.pores: Tubes 5-6 mm long, creamy white. Pores 1-3 per mm (sometimes even wider), irregularly angular to daedaleoid, slightly decurrent; white, staining pink to reddish if damaged.
mushrooms.flesh: Dual-layered (duplex), 8-10 mm thick. The upper (external) layer is soft and ochraceous, while the core or inner layer is a bit harder (corky) and more cream in colour.
mushrooms.habitat: On all kind of hardwood, often on buried roots, more rarely on conifers. Saprotrophic, causes white-rot, most of all in the roots of deciduous trees. Growing solitary or in smaller groups. Its main fruiting season is Late Summer to Autumn, but it can be found during the whole year.
mushrooms.confusion:
Young, irregular fruit bodies secrete/oozing red droplets. In this form it can be confused with Devil's Tooth (Hydnellum peckii) and/or Mealy Tooth (Hydnellum ferrugineum), but both species can be found exclusively in old conifer forests, near Pine or Spruce, also these species have spines (teeth), not wide pores.
The regular fruit bodies might be confused with the rarer Zoned Rosette (Podoscypha multizonata), pictured, which also prefers hardwoods, especially Oaks, but Zoned Rosette doesn't have visible pores. If we look it more carefully it more reminds of a pink to red stained Wood Cauliflower (Sparassis crispa) than a Blushing Rosette.
mushrooms.taste: Inedible, taste mild, but it has a strange mushroomy smell (some authors describes the smell as somewhat unpleasant).
mushrooms.facts:
It often forms irregular, aberrant fruit bodies. It could be hemispherical with its pores upside-down, but even if it forms its regular, rosette form, the so-called 'rosecomb mutation' is rather common. In mycology, the term 'rosecomb mutation' is used when any kind of distortions, lumps or malformations occur on the cap and makes visible the gills or the pores.
Its epithet (the 2nd part of the scientific name which identifies the species within the genus) - biennis - suggests it is biennal, but it is incorrect, and likely based on the really variable appearance of this species.

mushrooms.name: Horse Mushroom
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 10-16 cm. White, sometimes discoloured grey/brown, can be scaly or smooth. Starting spherical and opening out flat. Can bruise slightly yellow.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. When very young the gills are almost white but quickly turn from pale pink/grey to brown in more mature specimens. On unopened caps, the ring while still joined to the cap, looks like a 'cog wheel'.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-16 cm long, 2-3 cm diameter. Smooth and white with a double edged ring, can be finely flocculose toward the base.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. Can start fairly large but usually becomes damaged or shrinks to a ring. Has a double edge.
mushrooms.confusion: White, firm and bruising slightly yellow. The flesh has an aniseed smell.
mushrooms.taste: Pasture, meadows, lawns, road verges and parks, often growing in rings.
mushrooms.facts: Excellent, this is one of our favourites. The smell of aniseed is a good way to identify this mushroom. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: The Prince
mushrooms.capWidth: 10-16 but can be found up to 25cm
mushrooms.fruitingBody: Up to 25 cm. Spherical when young becoming convex. Covered in concentric chestnut brown scales on a white to pale yellow background. Can stain yellow on the edges where touched.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills starting off white to pink, maturing to dark brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-16 cm long, 2-3.5 cm diameter. White to pale cream and smooth above the skirt and covered in small brown scales below.
mushrooms.habitat: A large superior, pendulous skirt.
mushrooms.confusion: White sometimes with a yellow tinge where cut or bruised.
mushrooms.taste: Mixed woodland, particularly under conifers, lawns and roadsides, .
mushrooms.facts: Excellent. Mushroomy. The flesh smells of bitter almonds. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Pavement Mushroom
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. White and convex opening out to flat in mature specimens. The cap is often covered in mud and dust.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded, not joined to the stem. Gills off white/grey at first soon turning pink to dark brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-10cm long, 1.5-2 cm diameter. Robust, white and often tapering at the base.
mushrooms.habitat: Has an inferior, double edged skirt, obvious in this picture, not always so on other Pavement Mushrooms.
mushrooms.confusion: Meaty white flesh turning slightly pink on cutting.
mushrooms.taste: Roadsides, path edges, under trees, bare soil, gardens or manure.
mushrooms.facts: Strong and mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Medusa Mushroom
mushrooms.description: This really tasty Agaric is still considered rare in most books but it seems to have become more common in the UK over the last few years. It grows in clusters so it's found in large numbers but needs careful cleaning to remove all of the grit.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. A firm capped mushroom with brown triangular scales that are distinctly pointed and raised. The caps are often covered in soil as they burst through the ground so rapidly.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free from the stem. The gills start off white to pale pink and soon turn red brown to very dark brown.
mushrooms.flesh:
8-14 cm long, 1.5-2 cm diameter. The long stems have a tapered pointy base like a spindle and grow from a central point ,with the mushrooms in each cluster joined at the base of the stem.
It starts with a whitish colour but often becomes brown, sometimes scaly below the ring. The flesh will bruise red brown if damaged.
mushrooms.habitat: Has a thick, superior skirt that is usually towards the upper part of the stem. It is pale brown, scaly and can appear double ringed.
mushrooms.confusion: Initially white but rapidly turning red-brown when exposed and then becoming darker brown.
mushrooms.taste: Growing from soil usually under trees in mixed woodland and parks.
mushrooms.facts: Strong and mushroomy but the soil should be removed thoroughly otherwise a gritty meal will ensue. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Field Mushroom
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-8 cm. White, sometimes discoloured grey/brown, can be scaley or smooth. Starting spherical and opening out flat. Can bruise slightly pink. The cuticle often hangs down over the edge of the cap and is a good indicator of a Field Mushroom.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free from the stem. The gills start deep pink and soon turn to dark brown with maturity.
mushrooms.flesh: 5-7 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White and smooth above the ring, slightly scaly below, tapering at the base. The ring is delicate and only traces of it can usually be found.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior to intermediate. Small, slight and not very long lasting.
mushrooms.confusion: White, bruising slightly pink.
mushrooms.taste: Pasture, meadows, lawns, road verges and parks.
mushrooms.facts: Mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Macro Mushroom
mushrooms.description: Occasional, but being a large mushroom can often be seen from a distance. Can easily be confused with the Horse Mushroom but both are great tasting mushrooms so it's not a problem.
mushrooms.capWidth: 10-16 but can be found up to 25cm
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 10 to 25 cm when mature. Convex opening out flat becoming scaled and splitting at the edges when mature. Can remains of the veil hanging on the edges. Off-white sometimes with a pale yellow or brown flush.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Starting pale pink and turning to brown then almost black.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 2-3.5 cm diameter. White/cream and covered in floccules below the skirt. The stem tapers towards both the cap and base.
mushrooms.habitat: Has a flimsy, superior skirt with floccules on the underside.
mushrooms.confusion: White and firm, flushing red/pink in the stem when cut.
mushrooms.taste: Pastures, lawns and anywhere grassy. Growing in rings or sometimes individually.
mushrooms.facts: Mushroomy with a hint of almond or aniseed. Should be cooked before consumption. Smells of almonds to some, aniseed to others.

mushrooms.name: Scaly Wood Mushroom
mushrooms.description: A great tasting mushroom with flesh that bruises or oxidises red. Similar in looks to The Prince (Agaricus augustus), though smaller in size.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-15 cm. Spherical when young becoming convex. Covered in concentric slightly reddish brown scales on a white to pale yellow background.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded. Free of the stem. Gills starting pink, maturing to dark brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 5-10 cm long, 1.5-3 cm diameter. White to pale cream with red hints, smooth above the skirt and covered in small brown scales below.
mushrooms.habitat: A superior, single white fleshy ring hanging down with brown to grey floccules on the underside.
mushrooms.confusion: White, bruising or oxidising to pink/red. Can be yellowish in the base of the stem in older specimens.
mushrooms.taste: In open mixed woodland.
mushrooms.facts: Pleasantly mushroomy.

mushrooms.name: Inky Mushroom
mushrooms.description: A fairly common mushroom that can often be found in large numbers. When first spotted it usually causes a bit of excitement as it can resemble the Prince, then when smelt, disappointment sets in.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. White but covered with tiny smoky/grey or brown scales which are more dense towards the middle. Starting ovoid but becoming flat.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. The gills start pink and stay like that until finally becoming dark brown/black.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 1-1.2 cm diameter. White and slightly bulbous towards the base.
mushrooms.habitat: Has a large, superior, membranous skirt.
mushrooms.confusion: White discolouring slightly yellow and becoming brown.
mushrooms.taste: Mainly woodland in troops but can be found occasionally in grassland.

mushrooms.name: Dusky Scaled Mushroom
mushrooms.description: One of the brown scaled large Agaricus species. It has a distinctive, superior, pendulous ring with a cogwheel pattern on its underside. Might be weakly yellowing, and have a phenolic smell.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-12 cm across. Convex at first, then flattened. The skin is densely covered with light reddish brown to brown, appressed small scales. The centre of the cap usually darker than the rest.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Pinkish grey at first, then dark brown once the spores matured.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-13 cm tall, 0.7-1.4 cm in diameter. White, cylindrical with a bulbous base. Its surface is smooth.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior, membranous, thin with a distinct cogwheel pattern on the margin of the underside.
mushrooms.confusion: Fairly thin, soft. Initially white, may slightly yellowing at the base of the stem, otherwise may or may not bruising to faint pinkish-brown or brownish.
mushrooms.taste: Growing individually or in smaller groups on clay-rich or sandy calcareous soil in open deciduous woodlands, parks, gardens or cemeteries. Saprotrophic.
mushrooms.facts: Rather rare in England and Wales.

mushrooms.name: Almond Mushroom
mushrooms.description: This Agaricus species is native to North America and was regarded as a choice edible and cultivated. It is part of the Agaricus sub section containing the horse mushroom (Agaricus arvensis) and the Prince. These all have an almondy smell. The almond mushroom occurs in large groups unlike the Prince which tends to occur in groups of 2 or 3.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 3-10 cm. Convex, brown in the centre when young. Flattening with age with the brown splitting into scales
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free from the stem. Grey in immature specimens, turning brown with age.
mushrooms.flesh: 1-7 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. Stout, slightly bulbous base, white, with cottony layer (easily compressed with handling) at the top.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. Thick and floppy with woolly scales on the underside.
mushrooms.confusion: White, firm, thick. Smelling of almonds.
mushrooms.taste: In the UK, woodchip piles.
mushrooms.facts: Sweet and nutty.

mushrooms.name: Blushing Wood Mushroom
mushrooms.description: An fairly easy to identify Agaric with its blushing stem and flesh.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-10 cm. Spherical when young becoming convex. Pale brown fibre-like lines turning into small scales over a paler background. Any bruising or damage to the cap turns almost immediately to a striking red colour, see photos above.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills off-white becoming grey to red to dark brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-10 cm long, 1-1.2 cm diameter. White when young turning pale tan/grey. Can have a bulbous base.
mushrooms.habitat: A large, superior, skirt with triangular scales on the underside.
mushrooms.confusion: White, staining very red when cut and eventually fading to brown.
mushrooms.taste: Coniferous woodland but can be found with deciduous trees.
mushrooms.facts: Excellent, mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Wood Mushroom
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. Off-white/cream bruising ochraceous and becoming yellow with age.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills pale grey/pink at first turning a dark chocolate brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. White/off-white with a pendulous ring and slightly bulbous base.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. The underside is covered in triangular scales.
mushrooms.confusion: White and quite thin.
mushrooms.taste: Mixed woodland.
mushrooms.facts: Smells of aniseed, to some slightly almondy. Taste mushroomy. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Yellow Stainer
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. Starting rounded but with a slightly cubed shape, this flattens to a round shallow convex. White with very small scales, the cap can crack and turn grey in dry, sunny conditions. The cap bruises chrome yellow quite quickly.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Gills starting off white turning pink and becoming grey/brown when mature.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White/off-white with a skirt and slightly bulbous base.
mushrooms.habitat: Has a superior, pendulous, double edged white skirt, the one in the image is stained on the top surface by spores.
mushrooms.confusion: White bruising chrome yellow when cut especially at the base of the stem.
mushrooms.taste: Hedgerows, grassland, open woodland and beside roads and paths usually in large groups or rings.

mushrooms.name: Spring Fieldcap
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-8 cm. Dark grey/brown and greasy when young becoming dryer, off white tan to ochre until drying to near white with age. Convex opening out to almost flat usually remaining smooth and cracking in dry conditions. Can have remains of the veil on the edges.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded. Adnexed to almost free of the stem. Off white to pale grey to brown, becoming darker with age. Crowded with slightly wavy edges.
mushrooms.flesh: The young mushroom has a veil covering the gills, this soon detaches and can become the delicate and short lasting skirt.
mushrooms.habitat: 8-10 cm tall, 0.4-1 cm wide . Off white, darkening slightly towards the base. Can have a small delicate skirt. Has visible mycelial threads attached to the base if removed from it's medium.
mushrooms.confusion: Superior. Has a thin, delicate, ephemeral skirt.
mushrooms.taste: Off white, fibrous.
mushrooms.facts: Bitter when raw, less so after cooking.

mushrooms.name: Orange Peel Fungus
mushrooms.fruitingBody: No distinct cap, just a sheet of thin fragile bright orange flesh usually corrugated forming a rosette sometimes with multiple 'petals'. Can be completely flat to the ground, or more upright becoming 5cm tall.
mushrooms.pores: Does not have gills but the underside is paler than the upper surface and finely flocculose with a more matt finish.
mushrooms.flesh: Pores are too small to see with the naked eye but are on the upper surface of the cap to allow the spores to be released into the air and be blown away.
mushrooms.habitat: No real stem, more a very short thickening in the middle of the cap going into the ground.
mushrooms.confusion: Very thin, same colour as underside of cap.
mushrooms.taste: Saprobic on grass, gravel, or soil, usually compacted such as the side of paths.
mushrooms.facts: Locally very common, where you find one you will likely find many.

mushrooms.name: Snakeskin Grisette
mushrooms.description: One of the Grisette section within the broader Amanita genus. Typically a chunky mushroom, with the cap usually narrower than the length of the stem. It has no ring, emerges from a volva or sack structure, parts of which adhere to the cap. It is uncommon and its edibility is debatable, however it is very similar to other toxic species such as the panther cap so not recommended for the novice forager.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-14 cm. Chestnut brown with easily removed grey scales. Well defined striations around the edge and a pale margin in immature specimens. Starting ovoid, convex but flattening out with age.
mushrooms.pores: Typical Amanita, crowded white gills, free from the stem.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. No ring (as with all the Grisettes) but distinct shaggy grey zig-zag banding running across the stem - hence the term snakeskin.
mushrooms.habitat: It has a volva but this is fragile and collapses quickly
mushrooms.confusion: Mycorrhizal with deciduous trees, often in a parkland setting.
mushrooms.taste: The edibility of this mushroom is unclear, however the big potential for confusion here would be one of the other seriously poisonous Amanitas, particularly the Panthercap (Amanita pantherina) pictured. The Snakeskin Grissette does not have a skirt but these can be easily lost from look-a-like mushrooms leading to potential confusion. The stem of the Snakeskin Grisette should be a key identifier however this is not a mushroom for the novice forager!
mushrooms.facts: The species name (epithet), 'ceciliae' is honour of the Cecilia Berkeley, the wife of and contributor to the works of, the famous 19th century British mycologist, Miles Joseph Berkeley.

mushrooms.name: White False Death Cap
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-10 cm. A pure white cap with white patches of veil that can discolour to a tan-oche.
mushrooms.pores: Gills white, free of the stem and fairly crowded.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-11 cm long, 0.8-1.2 cm diameter. Pure white with an obvious volval sack and a bulbous base. The stem can be hollow in older specimens.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. The skirt is quite large.
mushrooms.confusion: A large obvious, marginate volva.
mushrooms.taste: White.
mushrooms.facts: White. Spherical.

mushrooms.name: False Deathcap
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-10 cm. An ivory white to pale yellow cap covered in off white patches of the remains of the veil.
mushrooms.pores: Gills white, free of the stem and fairly crowded.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-11 cm long, 0.8-1.2 cm diameter. Ivory white to yellow with an obvious volval sack and a bulbous base. The skirt is quite large and usually hangs down. The stem can be hollow in older specimens.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. Fairly fleshy.
mushrooms.confusion: Has an obvious, marginate volva.
mushrooms.taste: White.
mushrooms.facts: White. Spherical.

mushrooms.name: Orange Grisette
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. Starting egg shaped and then opening out to almost flat with a slightly darker umbo and radial striations at the edge of the cap. The colour can vary quite a bit but is usually yellow to orange.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. White to Off white.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. Pale orange with a snakeskin pattern, tapering towards the top.
mushrooms.habitat: Has a very obvious thick, long and white volval sack that can often be hidden under the surrounding vegetation or earth.
mushrooms.confusion: Thin and mainly white.
mushrooms.taste: Mycorrhizal, mainly grows with Birch or Beech, but can be found with some conifers.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly sweet and mushroomy.

mushrooms.name: Grey Spotted Amanita
mushrooms.description: This mushroom is not a safe mushroom for novice foragers as it can be difficult to distinguish it from the toxic Panthercap.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-11 cm. Grey-silver coloured to light brown to a darker red/brown and covered in off-white to grey scales. Spherical to convex to flat.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. White.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 1.5-2.5 cm diameter. White with an obvious skirt. The bottom of the stem is bulbous rather than appearing from a volva.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. The skirt has obvious striations on the upper surface running up to the start of the gills. This is an important part of the identification to differentiate from the toxic Panthercap, the Panthercap's skirt is smooth.
mushrooms.confusion: More of a bulbous base than a volva. There is no 'guttering' at the top of the volva.
mushrooms.taste: White.
mushrooms.facts: White. Ellipsoid. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.

mushrooms.name: Tawny Grisette
mushrooms.description: A fairly easy to identify edible Amanita but great care should be taken when identifying any Amanitas. The Tawny Grisette must be cooked before consumption.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. Orange/brown or 'tawny'. Ovoid at first then flattening out with a slight, darker umbo. The edge of the cap has striations in line with the gills underneath.
mushrooms.pores: Gills white, free of the stem and crowded. The gills can be different lengths terminating before reaching the cap edge or stem.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-12 cm long, 0.8-1.2 cm diameter. Starting white with a cap coloured flush developing when mature. Growing from an obvious sack like volva and tapering slightly towards the cap. No ring.
mushrooms.habitat: Has an obvious volval sack that can reach down a few centimetres into the earth.
mushrooms.confusion: White, usually hollow in the stem.
mushrooms.taste: Mixed woodland, moorland and heaths particularly on acid soil.
mushrooms.facts: Mushroomy.

mushrooms.name: Jewelled Amanita
mushrooms.description: Poisonous, said to be deadly as with some other Amanita species. Uncommon.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-10 cm. Convex to flat. Off-white, pale yellow covered in white pieces of velar remains or veil.
mushrooms.pores: Gills white, adnexed (slightly connected to stem), crowded.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-11 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White, slightly yellowish. Bulbous at the base with a delicate volva sometimes hollowing in the middle.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. A short lived, non striated skirt that is usually low down on the stem. Once gone, it usually leaves a small mark on the stem.
mushrooms.confusion: Has a slightly bulbous base with an obvious volva.
mushrooms.taste: White with pale yellow flush in the stem.
mushrooms.facts: White. Ovoid.

mushrooms.name: Fly Agaric
mushrooms.capHeight: 8-14 Though can be found much bigger occasionally.
mushrooms.capWidth: 8-14 Though can be found much bigger occasionally.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-14 cm. Hemispherical at first when it can sometimes be more orangey than red, then opening flat with a bright red cap covered in white to yellow scales which are the remains of the volvic sack. The scales can be washed off during rain to leave a smooth red cap.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. White to cream.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm tall, 1-2 cm diameter. Appearing from a volva (a bulbous egg like structure) the stem is white with shaggy remains of the volva sticking to it, it also has a skirt higher up the stem.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. Large, pendulous white/off white skirt, usually with yellow edges.
mushrooms.confusion: Has a bulbous volva with shaggy rings of scales around it rather than being marginate or having a sac like structure.
mushrooms.taste: White.
mushrooms.facts: White. Ellipsoid. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.

mushrooms.name: Panthercap
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. Convex, flattening a bit with age. Dark brown to slightly red brown covered in thick white scales or 'warts' left from the veil of the volva.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. White.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. White and shaggy under the skirt, smoother above.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. The skirt does not have the striations or lines that the Blusher or Excelsa have and is smooth although in the photo the skirt is a bit dry and wrinkled but still striation free.
mushrooms.confusion: Has an obvious, bulbous, marginate (with a 'gutter' running around the top edge) volva.
mushrooms.taste: White, sometimes hollow in the stem.
mushrooms.facts: White. Broadly ovate. You should scrape your spores into a small pile to get an accurate spore colour.

mushrooms.name: Deathcap
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. Convex at first then opening and flattening. The cap colour can vary from olive green to dirty yellow or even tan brown. Slimy when wet but still looking shiny when dry.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. White to cream.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. White with a bulbous base and surrounded by a thin veil (volva) which is sack-like at ground height, tapering slightly towards the cap. The top of the volva will often be found attached to the stem more than halfway up, looking like a skirt.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. White with obvious striations under the skirt sometimes visible on top.
mushrooms.confusion: A very obvious deep volva that can be under the ground surface.
mushrooms.taste: White.
mushrooms.facts: DO NOT try any part of this mushroom.

mushrooms.name: The Blusher
mushrooms.description: Common and available before many other species are out, this is a good eating mushroom but difficult to identify for the novice forager and must be well cooked before consumption. Great care should be taken identifying this fungi.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 8-12 cm. Flesh coloured to light brown to a darker red/brown sometimes with a yellow flush and covered in off-white to grey scales. Spherical to convex to flat.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. Can develop pink to red spots where damaged.
mushrooms.flesh: 9-12 cm long, 1-2.5 cm diameter. Scaly and off white to grey/red/brown below the skirt, generally smoother and whiter above.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. The skirt is an important identification tool as the top has fine grooves or striations running from the stem outwards.
mushrooms.confusion: Young Blushers have an obvious volva but as the mushroom matures the bottom of the stem is bulbous rather than being marginate.
mushrooms.taste: White but 'blushing' pink to red when bruised or exposed to air.
mushrooms.facts: White. Ovoid.

mushrooms.name: Grisettes
mushrooms.description:
From now on we use “Grisettes” as a colloquial term to refer all the ringless Amanita species (Amanita sect. Vaginatae). Their species level determination, based on macroscopic features only, is anything but easy and except for a few characteristic species, rather impossible. Thankfully there are a few features that help to recognise them as one of the Grisettes.
All the Grisettes are medium or big size agarics (mushrooms with distinct cap, gills and stem), their cap is smooth (except Snakeskin Grisette (Amanita ceciliae) which has thick velar greyish patches on it, and a few other species in this group), margin of their cap is striated, gills are white to cream coloured, there is no ring or skirt around their stem which could be either smooth, covered with a snakeskin-like pattern or with small flakes. Their stem is cylindrical or slightly tapering towards the top of the stem (apex), their volva is saccate (looks like a sac) and very often remains in the soil if you try to pick it.
Although they are considered edible, caution must be taken if foraging for this mushroom as it can look similar to a Deathcap (Amanita phalloides) or another toxic member of the genus.
mushrooms.fruitingBody:
The cap of all Grisettes starts ovate but will flatten out, usually retaining an umbo. The colour of the cap is really variable, from almost pure White to Beige, Brown or Grey, with a darker centre and striations at the edge of the cap in line with the gills below.
Most of the Grisettes don't usually have any remains of the volva sticking to the cap.
mushrooms.pores: The gills are generally White, but sometimes they could be Cream coloured too. They are crowded and usually free of the stem although they can be adnexed, (slightly joined to the stem).
mushrooms.flesh: The colour of the stem is mostly rather similar to the cap's colour. It is very often smooth, but sometimes it could have a snakeskin pattern on. Commonly cylindrical, but can be tapering slightly towards the apex (top of the stem).
mushrooms.habitat: Has a sack like volva that can be hidden in the undergrowth.
mushrooms.confusion: Thin, white and can become hollow in the stem.
mushrooms.taste: Associated with different broadleaved and coniferous trees, in some locations with small shrubs or herbaceous plants.
mushrooms.facts: Not common.

mushrooms.name: Warted Amanita
mushrooms.description: A very robust (chunky) rare white Amanita. Large, solid, and almost clublike before the cap opens. This is a mushroom that can be spotted from a hundred metres away and with care identified despite there being a number of white Amanita.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 10-20 cm in diameter when opened, starting off domed and flattening out with maturity. White or off white with large dirty grey lumps of veil attached. These hang around and off the edge.
mushrooms.pores: Very white, crowded, adnexed (gills attached with less than full depth to stem) which is unusual for the Amanita genus which are usually free.
mushrooms.flesh: Fragments of the veil adhere to the cap and margins of the cap as large grey scales
mushrooms.habitat: 10-20 cm long, 2-5 cm diameter. Very substantial and club like, white, rough and mealy. There is no substantial volva like some Amanita but there are flaky remnants ringing the bottom of the stem.
mushrooms.confusion: The skirt is quite large but very insubstantial almost lacy and high up the stem (superior). It is easily broken by handling or disturbance reducing it to a short fragment sitting on the stem.
mushrooms.taste: White unchanging.
mushrooms.facts: White

mushrooms.name: Destroying Angel
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-11 cm. Convex then conical to almost flat but usually retaining an umbo. The cap is pure white and can be viscid.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded and free of the stem. White.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. White with a fibrous skin. As with other Amanitas the stem starts from a bulbous volva but the skirt is fragile and often missing or slight.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. A slight skirt with no striations which can be easily damaged or missing.
mushrooms.confusion: A large bulbous volva that can be deep under the surface.
mushrooms.taste: Pure white.
mushrooms.facts: DO NOT try any of this mushroom.

mushrooms.name: Honey Fungus
mushrooms.description: This tasty and very common mushroom can give a small amount of people gastric upsets so should be tried in small amounts the first time it is eaten. It should always be cooked before consumption.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-12 cm. Conical when young, then convex, then flattening and even having upturned edges. Honey coloured, ochre or brown with a darker slight umbo and sometimes concentric circles of darker scales.
mushrooms.pores: Crowded. Adnate to slightly decurrent. Gills start white turning yellow to brown and often darker.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-14 cm long, 0.5-1.5 cm diameter. The chunky Honey fungus has a fairly thick, scaly, white to yellow brown stem which is usually bulbous at the base. The slender fungus is thinner, generally smoother and tapers towards the base and can be white to yellow to red/brown.
mushrooms.habitat: Superior. The ring is usually very high on the stem and can appear as a double ring with chrome yellow edges.
mushrooms.confusion: White.
mushrooms.taste: Growing in large clusters on deciduous trunks, stumps or dead wood but can also be found in grass as the rhizomorphs spread looking for more trees to infect.
mushrooms.facts: Good and found in large numbers. Must be cooked before consumption but can still cause slight gastric upsets in a small number of people.

mushrooms.name: Giant Funnel
mushrooms.description: A large chunky mushroom which can be found in fairly large numbers and is edible to most but can cause gastric upsets in some. This doesn't really matter as the mushrooms are usually infested with maggots, even when young, making them more maggot than flesh.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 10-40 cm. The cap starts ivory white and convex but soon flattens out with a downward turned edge before becoming funnel shaped and turning a tan/off white colour. This mushroom can be very varied in size with the cap measuring from ten to forty five cm across with the larger specimens being rarer.
mushrooms.pores: The gills are decurrent (running down the stem) and forked. White and crowded becoming off white with age.
mushrooms.flesh: 4-8 cm long, 2.5-4 cm diameter. Thick, can be up to 5cm. White with vertical 'fibres' which can discolour to tan.
mushrooms.habitat: White, fairly tough and usually full of maggots.
mushrooms.confusion: Open woodland and hedgerows, grassland and beside country lanes.
mushrooms.taste:
The Fleecy Milkcap, pictured, can look very similar but produces latex from the gills and flesh, unlike the Giant Funnel.
The Trooping Funnel can look similar but has a much longer stem, an umbo in the middle of the cap, is more tan coloured and does not produce latex.
Some members of genus Clitocybe can look like the Giant Funnel but the clue is in the name, the cap can be up to forty+ cm in diameter with a short, thick stem distinguishing it from most of the Clitocyboid species.
mushrooms.facts: Not common.

mushrooms.name: Jelly Ears
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 3-7cm. The fruiting body is ear-shaped. It is smooth or undulating, covered in very fine down and is tan, red/brown in colour.
mushrooms.pores: The underside is smoother and lighter than the top surface.
mushrooms.flesh: Translucent, thin and jelly like.
mushrooms.habitat: Mainly growing on dead or living elder in large numbers but can be found occasionally on other wood.
mushrooms.confusion:
As long as you only collect these from elder trees they can only be Jelly Ears.
Some Pezizas, pictured, can look similar but these don't tend to grow on elder and grow with the 'cup shape' facing up, the Jelly Ears face down. listening to the ground.
mushrooms.taste: White. Sausage shaped.
mushrooms.facts:
Can be picked in its dry state and re-hydrated when needed or picked fresh and dried at home.
Can withstand frosts and grows all year round.
Named after the apostle, Judas, who allegedly hanged himself from an Elder tree.
Until recently the common English names Jelly Ear and Wood Ear were used interchangeably in the English speaking world. However, in the light of the recent taxonomic changes within the genus Auricularia, we would recommend to stick to the recommended common English name by the British Mycological Society, which is Jelly Ear. Our Jelly Ear (Auricularia auricula-judae) is a European species, and it is not native to Asia, while Wood Ear (Auricularia heimuer) is native to Asia, and it is not native to Europe. They could be used in the same way in the kitchen, but they are two different species now.

mushrooms.name: Tripe Fungus
mushrooms.description: An inedible relative of our Jelly Ear. From the top, it might remind you of Turkeytail, but once you have checked its underneath, everything becoming clear.
mushrooms.fruitingBody:
1-3 cm across. The fruiting body is ear shaped, often resupinate (covers the substrate without forming a cap) or semi-resupinate (only forms a small cap), often forms fused-emerged big patches on the substrate.
Upper surface is irregular, wavy or lobed, hairy (often covered with algae) and zonated. Its margin is grey-white, the concentric zones are reddish-brown, grey, ochre and/or white in colour.
mushrooms.pores: Does not have gills. The fertile (under) surface is smooth when young, becoming wrinkled or vein-like with age. Whitish or pale grey at first, darkening to reddish-brown when mature.
mushrooms.flesh: Thin, gelatinous, soft when young and moist, becoming tough and somewhat brittle with age.
mushrooms.habitat: Saprotrophic, causing white-rot. Growing on dead wood and stumps of various hardwood genera the whole year long if the environmental conditions are right, but in the UK the most common substrates are Elm and Beech. The individual fruit bodies often emerge and form a big patch of tripe fungus on its substrate.
mushrooms.confusion:
Jelly Ear (Auricularia auricula-judae), has smooth, faintly hairy skin, concolorous with its fertile underside.
Turkeytail (Trametes versicolor), pictured, has a rather similarly zonated top, but has less hairy skin, and has a white pore surface.
Crusts (Stereum spp.) have thin, leathery flesh and their fertile underside is never wrinkled or vein-like.
mushrooms.taste: Spore print is white. Spores are cylindrical, colourless (hyaline), smooth with drops.
mushrooms.facts: The genus name, Auricularia, refers to the ear shape of the species within the genus. The epithet (the 2nd part of the scientific name which identifies the species within the genus) mesenterica has Greek origin (mesenterion or μεσεντέριον) and refers to the 'middle of the intestine' or tripe.

mushrooms.name: Smoky Bracket
mushrooms.description: A very common, small, annual polypore mushroom with grey pore surface.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 3-7 cm across, thin, convex to nearly flat, fan-shaped or shelf-like, often overlapping or even rosette-like, usually in groups. It could be resupinate if growing on the underside of the host/substrate. Margin is white, blackening with age. Its skin is faintly hairy (tomentose) with faint concentric zones at first, could be almost completely hairless and suede-like with age.
mushrooms.pores: Tubes up to 1 mm long, pale grey to grey. Pores 4-7 per mm, angular to irregularly rounded, smoke-grey, blackening if damaged.
mushrooms.flesh: Thin, elastic and has two layers. Under the skin it is whitish, while greyish to blackish above the tubes.
mushrooms.habitat: On the dead wood of hardwoods, especially Beech, but rarely on conifers. Saprotrophic, causes white-rot.
mushrooms.confusion:
Especially younger fruit bodies could be easily confuse with Turkeytail (Trametes versicolor), pictured, but its skin has more colour and its pore surface is much brighter white.
Its close relative, Big Smoky Bracket (Bjerkandera fumosa) somewhat bigger (4-10 cm across), its cap is paler in colour and growing mostly on Sycamore, but also on Alder, Sweet Chestnut or other hardwood genera. There is a dark layer between the two layers of its flesh.
mushrooms.taste: Spore print is white. Spores elliptical, smooth and colourless (hyaline).

mushrooms.name: Oak Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. Rusty to red brown or sometimes lighter, often irregular, sometimes has a 'cracked' skin especially near the centre.
mushrooms.pores: Lemon yellow, tight sponge like pores that darken a bit with age. These will bruise to a blue colour.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-10 cm long, 3-4 cm diameter. Straight or clavate, club shaped, lemon yellow at the top with yellow reticulation, (a mesh or net like covering) then usually a change to a pale orange to red towards the base.
mushrooms.habitat: White to pale yellow. Turning pale blue when cut, the base bruising rusty brown.
mushrooms.confusion: Mainly around Oak but will grow with other deciduous trees.
mushrooms.taste: Other Boletes. Although the Oak Bolete is quite distinctive care should be taken when trying to identify this mushroom as it breaks the simple edible rules for Boletes (if a bolete has red on it anywhere, do not eat it and if it stains blue when cut, again, don't eat it).
mushrooms.facts: Uncommon.

mushrooms.name: Bitter Beech Bolete
mushrooms.description: Although not poisonous, this mushroom will ruin any dish you put it in due to its extreme bitterness.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. Cloudy grey with some tan hints. Starting a bit downy but becoming smooth with age. Can crack towards the centre.
mushrooms.pores: Lemon yellow, tight, sponge like pores which bruise a pale blueish green.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-10cm long, 3-4.5 cm diameter. Lemon yellow at the top going into red and finally brown at the bottom, this is covered in a light coloured reticulation. The stem can vary from swollen to slim and has traces of 'roots' when pulled up.
mushrooms.habitat: Pale yellow but turning immediately off white on cutting and changing to blue after a short time.
mushrooms.confusion: Beech and oak but will grow with other deciduous trees, sometimes conifers.
mushrooms.taste: Other Boletes, particularly the Rooting Bolete (Caloboletus radicans), pictured.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly common.

mushrooms.name: Rooting Bolete
mushrooms.description: Although not poisonous this mushroom is so bitter it will ruin any dish you put it in.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-12 cm. Off white to grey/brown, darkening with age. Can get very big and uneven and will show cracking on the surface of the cap.
mushrooms.pores: Has yellow, tight, sponge like pores which bruise blue.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-10 long, 3-4 cm diameter . Lemon yellow at the top becoming pale red or brown and 'dirtier' towards the swollen, slightly rooting base. The stem has a light coloured reticulation which is easiest to see towards the apex.
mushrooms.habitat: Yellow when first cut but quickly changing to off white in the cap and then turning blue.
mushrooms.confusion: Usually with oak and beech but will grow with other deciduous trees.
mushrooms.taste: Other Boletes, particularly Bitter Beech Bolete (Caloboletus calopus), pictured.

mushrooms.name: Peppery Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-8 cm. Cinnamon to brown, shiny even when dry and can crack with age.
mushrooms.pores: Angular, cinnamon to brown pores. Unchanging when bruised.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-9 cm long, 0.5-2 cm diameter. Fairly thin for a Bolete, yellow to cinnamon coloured with hints of red and vertically striated. The stem is chrome yellow at the base but this can often be covered by earth.
mushrooms.habitat: Yellow with a slight reddish flush in the cap, chrome yellow at the very base of the stem.
mushrooms.confusion: With Birch or Pine and often found in association with where Fly Agarics grow.
mushrooms.taste: A small nibble on this Bolete will soon give its identity away due to its hot peppery taste.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly common.

mushrooms.name: Chestnut Bolete
mushrooms.description:
This is a great mushroom to find because if you look around nearby, there will usually be many more underfoot.
The Chestnut Bolete is distinguished from true Boletes by its pale yellow spore print and the hollow stem.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 3-8 cm. Pale orange to tawny to darker brown coloured starting convex but soon flattening out. Downy when young becoming smooth. When the mushroom becomes old it usually discolours white from the attack of a mould, the Boletus Eater (Hypomyces chrysospermus).
mushrooms.pores: White pores that discolour to off-white/pale yellow with age and bruise pale grey.
mushrooms.flesh: 3-8 cm long, 1-2.5 cm diameter. Off-white to pale orange to chestnut coloured with white flesh. The stem becomes hollow in most specimens.
mushrooms.habitat: White and unchanging when exposed to air, very occasionally with a pink flush.
mushrooms.confusion: Usually with oaks or sweet chestnut but will grow with other hardwoods in woods, gardens, parks and verges.
mushrooms.taste: Also lookout for the rare Cornflower Bolete (Gyroporus cyanescens), a related and similar mushroom that turns vividly blue wherever it is touched. As it's rare it's best to avoid picking it.
mushrooms.facts: Uncommon, can be found locally in the South of England.

mushrooms.name: Ascot Hat
mushrooms.description: The genus name, Hortiboletus, refers to the latin 'hortus' meaning garden where the Hortiboletus bubalinus can often be found growing with Poplar or Lime trees.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-10 cm. Pale brown with slight red or yellow hues, lighter towards the edge. Starts of rounded but becoming flatter and more uneven with age.
mushrooms.pores: Yellow to pale yellow sometimes with olivaceous hints. Angular not round and bruising blue/green.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-10 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. Fairly thin for a Bolete, pale background covered in vertical red 'fibres'.
mushrooms.habitat: Off white/yellow in the stem. White in the cap staining pink under the cuticle and blue above the pores.
mushrooms.confusion: Often in parks, gardens and urban environments under Lime or Poplar trees.
mushrooms.taste: Other Boletes but none of the poisonous varieties.
mushrooms.facts: Not reported much before 2000 but becoming more common or more often reported.

mushrooms.name: Ruby Bolete
mushrooms.description: These are fairly rare mushrooms in the UK and as they also have a soapy taste they are best left for photographs.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-8 cm. Scarlet red fading to olivaceous red, dry and slightly velvety. Starting convex but flattening out with age.
mushrooms.pores: Yellow angular pores that fade a bit greenish with age and bruise blue slowly.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-10 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. Red and striated with a more yellow apex and yellow mycelial threads.
mushrooms.habitat: Yellowish staining blue when cut with red to pink just under the cap cuticle.
mushrooms.confusion: Grassy woodland or or parks and gardens particularly with oak sometimes with beech.
mushrooms.taste: A fairly distinctive mushroom with a couple of rare lookalikes in the Bolete family.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly rare.

mushrooms.name: Bay Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-8 cm. Often starts spherical opening to convex and flattening with age. A bit velvety when young, smooth and shiny when mature. Dark brown or brown/brick coloured, slightly slimy when wet.
mushrooms.pores: Pale yellow pores, bruising rapidly to a blue/green.
mushrooms.flesh: 5-8 cm long, 1-4 cm diameter. Pale brown looking vertically fibrous over a paler yellow/tan background. Can be quite thick.
mushrooms.habitat: White/pale yellow. Staining pale blue/green on cutting especially in the cap.
mushrooms.confusion: Mixed woodland.
mushrooms.taste: Can look like other Boletes (see Penny Bun, pictured,) but if you stick to the simple rule of avoiding any Bolete with red on the stem, pores or cap and any Bolete whose flesh turns rapidly blue when cut you will only pick edible Boletes. You will be missing out on some good edibles with that rule but you will be keeping yourself 100% safe.
mushrooms.facts: Very common and widespread in the UK.

mushrooms.name: Aspen Bolete
mushrooms.description: A scarce member of the Leccinum genus of the Boletes. Very similar to and probably often mistaken for the Orange Bolete, Leccinum aurantiacum. Usually found in small groups, a very solid and quite tall mushroom with a distinctive orange coloured cap and and a pale stem. Like other orange capped boletes needs thorough cooking.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-10 cm. Orangey red, domed even in mature specimens. Flaps of skin hanging over the edge up to 6mm lasting into maturity.
mushrooms.pores: Off white to grey small round pores.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-20 cm long and 2-5vcm diameter. Proportionally long. Very solid, tapering towards the cap. White with floccules (small raised protrusions found on the stem of the Leccinum genus). These floccules can be a gingery/foxy colour in some areas, but never dense dark brown. Base can be swollen and blue.
mushrooms.habitat: Firm, thick. White at first, then sometimes turning wine red, then greys to almost black. Sometimes turning blue in the base.
mushrooms.confusion: Associates with Populus species, i.e, various Poplars and Aspens.
mushrooms.taste: Orange Birch Bolete (Leccinum versipelle), pictured, is very similar but only grows with Birch, has a lighter cap colour and has dark brown to black floccules on the stem unlike the orange/brown floccules of the Orange Bolete.
mushrooms.facts: This has been known by the name Leccinum aurantiacum for many years due to a mistake by the original scientist who described it. Later studies decided that this was incorrect and taxonomic law meant that the name had to be applied to a different mushroom - so a new name was given to this species. All very confusing, but new work has clarified the matter.

mushrooms.name: Orange Bolete
mushrooms.description: Although known to be associated with Oak, this mushroom can also be found under Poplar, Aspen, Beech or Birch, making the identification between other Leccinums difficult. Must be well cooked before consumption.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-15 cm. Fox orange/brown but light blue/green where damaged. Starting ovate opening to broadly convex and staying like that until finally flattening out a bit with age, can be slightly downy especially when young. The top edge of the cap overhangs the pores which can help with identification.
mushrooms.pores: Off white to cream quite tightly packed pores which can bruise grey with a slight pink hue.
mushrooms.flesh: 12-18 cm long, 1.5-4 cm diameter. Off white background covered in orange/brown floccules. Usually starts quite bulbous and short but thins out and elongates becoming almost straight with age.
mushrooms.habitat: White when first cut but turning dark grey with hints of purple after a couple of minutes.
mushrooms.confusion: Grows with Oaks but can more often be found with Poplar or Aspen and can also be found with Beech and Birch.
mushrooms.taste: Foxy Bolete (Leccinum vulpinum) can be found under Pine and Spruce and it bruises blue-green at the stem base.
mushrooms.facts: Not overly common.

mushrooms.name: Slate Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-15 cm across, sub-spherical, then convex to flattened, its margin often projecting a little. Its skin is finely downy to smooth, pale brown, buff, ochre-brown to grey-brown, often cracking with age.
mushrooms.pores: Whitish cream, to greyish-brown, bruising buff-brown. The pores are very small.
mushrooms.flesh: 5-15 cm long, 2-5 cm diameter. Robust, cylindrical, spindle-shape (fusiform) or swollen around the middle (ventricose). Whitish with dark grey-black squamules, in a net-like pattern. The top of the stem (apex) is often paler, bruising light brownish when touched. Stem base stains blue-green.
mushrooms.habitat: White to off white, turning pink to violaceous when cut, after a few minutes it turns a darker grey to black. Might be staining blue in maggot holes. It is thick, firm to soft in the cap, fibrous in the stem.
mushrooms.confusion: Ectomycorrhizal, associated with Poplars. Growing solitary or more commonly in groups from early Summer to mid-Autumn. Prefers open woodlands, parks and cemeteries.
mushrooms.taste: Saffron Bolete (Leccinellum crocipodium) prefers Oak, Beech and Hornbeam, has ochre-yellow to yellow-brown cap and doesn't stain blue at the stem base.
mushrooms.facts: Widespread but occasional in the South and Southeast.

mushrooms.name: Brown Birch Bolete
mushrooms.description: This common edible Autumn mushroom is not as firm and tasty as the best boletes, but mixed with other mushrooms it's not bad. Because it's a very common mushroom it can really help to bulk your basket and it's a really easy one for beginners.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. Smooth, starting hemispherical and flattening with age. Varying shades of brown. Sticky when wet.
mushrooms.pores: White to white/greyish pores discolouring with age and bruising brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-13 cm long, 1.5-3 cm diameter. White to grey with a covering of small dark scales or floccules, giving it a dirty appearance. Tapering towards the top.
mushrooms.habitat: White, unchanging when cut or turning slightly pink but turning black when cooked.
mushrooms.confusion: Under and around Birch trees.
mushrooms.taste:
The Slate Bolete (leccinum duriusculum), pictured, is very similar but grows in association with Poplars not Birch as the Brown Birch Bolete does.
Other Leccinums, there are a few with brown caps which can be hard to distinguish but none of these Leccinums are poisonous.
The orange cap Leccinums are toxic when raw and should be cooked for at least 15 minutes (see Orange Birch Bolete and Orange Oak Bolete).
mushrooms.facts: Common.

mushrooms.name: Orange Birch Bolete
mushrooms.description: A tasty member of the greater Bolete family. This mushroom can sometimes also be known as the Boletus testaceoscaber or Boletus rufescens.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. Starting ovate opening to broadly convex and staying like that until finally flattening out a bit with age, can be slightly downy. Orange to red orange/brown or even yellowish, this mushroom can vary greatly in cap colour and the versipelle used to be thought of as several different Leccinum species. The top edge of the cap overhangs the pores a little bit which can help with identification.
mushrooms.pores: white to pale yellow sponge-like pores, can be a bit grey/brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-13 cm long, 1.5-3.5 cm diameter. White to off-white mottled with small brown to black scales which give it a dirty appearance. The stem can be longer than the diameter of the cap.
mushrooms.habitat: White/pale grey turning dark blue/green in the stem to dark grey/black on cooking.
mushrooms.confusion: Growing under birch trees, especially on acid heathland and wood edges.
mushrooms.taste:
The Orange Bolete (Leccinum aurantiacum), pictured, looks almost identical and can grow with Birch but the two are edible if well cooked.
Aspen Bolete (Leccinum albostipitatum) is a rare find in the UK and it grows exclusively with Poplar and Aspen. Its stem is initially white with the floccules turning reddish with age.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly common.

mushrooms.name: Scarletina Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-11 cm. The cap starts bay to brown and velvety but soon becomes smooth, the edge of the cap is usually lighter, the whole cap can lighten with age.
mushrooms.pores: Has sponge like pores starting yellow-orange and becoming red-brown, sometimes staying lighter around the edge. The pores bruise easily and stain dark blue to black.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-11 cm long, 2-4.5 cm diameter. The stem is yellow with a dense covering of red dots. Where touched it tends to discolour to dark blue/black. Sliced down the middle the flesh turns instantly dark blue-black especially towards the base of the stem.
mushrooms.habitat:
The flesh starts yellow but stains instantly blue-black when exposed to air, this fades after some time.
It doesn't retain the blue staining after cooking.
mushrooms.confusion: Mostly associated with Beech and Oak but can be found in mixed or coniferous woodland.
mushrooms.taste:
The Lurid Bolete (Suillellus luridus) can look similar but has a red mesh on the stem, pictured, unlike the red dots on the Scarletina.
Most toxic Boletes will have a mesh pattern on the stem rather than dots.
In particular the Devil's Bolete (Rubroboletus satanas) is a really toxic species, but again it's possible to tell the two apart by the spots of red on the stem of the Scarletina while the Devils Bolete has a red mesh. Also the cap of the Devil's Bolete being a chalky white but this is less reliable as the cap can fade on older Scarletina Boletes.
Deceiving bolete (Suillellus queletii) also has dots on the stem but they're yellow to buff/grey and not red. When cut in cross section it also turns blue but the flesh at the base of the stem should have a vinaceous red colour. Confusing the two would be a harmless mistake as both are edible after cooking and very good.
mushrooms.facts: Common.

mushrooms.name: Parasitic Bolete
mushrooms.description: The mushroom is not listed as poisonous but sites vary on its edibility so we will err on the side of caution and say it is not edible.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 3-6 cm. Brown to yellow to tawny and slightly downy. Convex to opening out flat. The margin is inrolled.
mushrooms.pores: Does not have gills but sponge like angular pores which start yellow and turn to an olive brown. The pores are decurrent. May colour slightly blue when bruised.
mushrooms.flesh: 3-6 cm long, 0.7 1.5 cm diameter. Dirty yellow to pale brown, tapering towards the bottom. Slightly fibrillose, slightly flocculose on close inspection.
mushrooms.habitat: Bright yellow but darkening towards the base. Does not change colour when exposed to air.
mushrooms.confusion: Exclusively growing from the Common Earthball, Sceloderma citrinum. Appearing from where the Earthball touches the ground. Earthballs can be found in most types of woodland and favours mossy or peaty soil on heathland
mushrooms.taste: When found growing from an Earthball this can be no other mushroom.
mushrooms.facts: The name parasiticus was given when it was thought the fungus grew on live Earthballs but it is now thought it grows only on decaying mushrooms.

mushrooms.name: Devil's Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-11 cm. Convex but often rough and undulating. Off-white with light tan, buff, sometimes with red tones and can crack when dry.
mushrooms.pores: Fine blood red pores fading to orange, bruising blue/green.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-9 cm long, 4-10 cm diameter. Swollen towards the base, red/orange turning chrome yellow towards the apex. Usually covered in a fine red reticulation or mesh.
mushrooms.habitat: White to pale yellow, turning pale blue when exposed to the air.
mushrooms.confusion: With oak, beech and other broad-leaved trees.
mushrooms.taste:
Bitter Beech Bolete (Caloboletus calopus), pictured, has yellow pores.
Lurid Bolete (Suillellus luridus), looks similar but tends to have a darker cap and the stem is not as bulbous.
Bilious bolete (Rubroboletus legaliae) looks very similar but has red or pink tones in the grey cap.

mushrooms.name: Old Man of the Woods
mushrooms.description: Old Man of the Woods is not a commonly found mushroom in the UK, it is a rare find but is also hard to find amongst leaf litter. Due to it's rarity in the UK we advise leaving this strange looking Bolete for admiration only.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-9 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. Convex flattening as it matures. The cap is covered in grey to black triangular scales, the cap is off white to pale grey between the scales.
mushrooms.pores: Fairly large angular pores that are off white to grey to almost black with age. The pores will bruise red at first before turning black.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-11cm. Covered in dense scales below where the partial veil was attached, less so above. The stem is very firm.
mushrooms.habitat: Starting white to off white but staining red then black on exposure to air.
mushrooms.confusion: Mainly found with deciduous trees but can be found with conifers.
mushrooms.taste: This mushroom is very distinctive and is easy to identify.
mushrooms.facts: Black. Ellipsoid and covered in a fine mesh.

mushrooms.name: Lurid Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-11 cm. There are some variants of the Lurid Bolete, in some the cap starts pale yellow and velvety but soon becomes smooth and stays yellow-brown, in others the cap is dark red-brown with paler flesh where the cap has been damaged. Peach colour or grey-sepia forms are also common.
mushrooms.pores: Pores starting yellow-orange and becoming deeper red but staying lighter around the edge. The pores bruise easily and stain dark blue to black.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-11 cm long, 1-3 cm diameter. The stem is yellow to orange with a dark red mesh which turns to yellow at the very top of the stem. When cut down the middle the stem flushes blue at the top fading to pale orange-yellow at the bottom with a wine red area towards the base.
mushrooms.habitat: When sliced down the middle the flesh turns from yellow to blue-black instantly but leaves a wine red line between the cap flesh and the top of the pores, there is also usually a wine red region towards the bottom of the sliced stem. This staining fades after a little time. The red line can just be made out in this photo.
mushrooms.confusion: Deciduous woodland, particularly Beech and Oak but can sometimes be found in association with conifers.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly common.

mushrooms.name: Bovine Bolete
mushrooms.description: This mushroom can be found growing in large numbers in late Autumn. Like other Suillus mushrooms, whilst being edible, it is best to remove the slimy skin of the cap and pores before consumption, which unfortunately doesn't leave much mushroom!
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-9 cm. Pale orange-yellow with grey to pink hues. Wet to the touch with a pale edge to the cap.
mushrooms.pores: Orange-tan to pale-olive pores that are angular not round.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-10 cm long, 0.5-1 cm diameter. Concolourous with the cap with hints of pink at the bottom and on any exposed mycelium.
mushrooms.habitat: Mainly white/off white with some pale orange/buff colouring towards the base of the stem.
mushrooms.confusion: Coniferous woodland especially with pine.
mushrooms.taste:
Other Suillus but as none are toxic this should not prove a problem.
The Larch Bolete (Suillus grevillei) looks similar but has a ring zone on the stem.
mushrooms.facts: Common and widespread.

mushrooms.name: Larch Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-9cm. Bright yellow, darkening to burnt orange on older specimens. Starting convex but flattening in older mushrooms. The cap is viscid and looks shiny even when the weather is dry and is covered in slime. The variant badius has a chestnut brown cap.
mushrooms.pores: Sponge like, angular, bright yellow pores that darken with maturity and will bruise a rust colour.
mushrooms.flesh: 8-11 cm long, 1.5-2 cm diameter. Yellow with brown scales underneath the veil like skirt and smooth above. Before the mushroom fully opens the pores are covered by a fine web like veil which joins the edge of the cap to the stem, when this comes away it forms the skirt.
mushrooms.habitat: Has a ring zone left from the veil over the pores, it is not a true skirt.
mushrooms.confusion: Yellow-orange and holding a lot of water.
mushrooms.taste: Under and around Larch trees.
mushrooms.facts: This mushroom holds so much water that it really needs drying to get a flavour and texture from but as it holds so much water it dries to next to nothing, otherwise it can be added to soups and stews to bulk them out. Should be cooked before consumption.

mushrooms.name: Slippery Jack
mushrooms.description: This slimy topped mushroom is common to Pine plantations and can usually be found close to paths in late Summer and Autumn. One of the few Bolete species to have a skirt.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-12 cm long, 2-3 cm diameter. Dark brown to purple/brown with a very glutinous cap when wet, more rusty brown when dry. Starting convex and broadly flattening with age.
mushrooms.pores: The pores are round, tightly packed and lemon yellow to dull yellow. When young they are covered by a veil which will break free from the cap forming the skirt.
mushrooms.flesh: The veil completely covers the pores on young mushrooms.
mushrooms.habitat: 5-9cm. Off white to yellow, more yellow above the skirt and covered in small brown granular spots.
mushrooms.confusion: Thick and white underneath, brown above from the dropping spores, on older mushrooms the underside can become pale lavender coloured or the whole ring can become just a mark on the stem.
mushrooms.taste: White, sometimes with a red/purple flush towards the base. Unchanging when exposed to air.
mushrooms.facts: Brown. Subfusiform. The image is of the upper surface of the skirt where it has caught some dropping spores.

mushrooms.name: Velvet Bolete
mushrooms.description: Mainly found on acid moorland/heathland with Scots Pine, particularly in Scotland and the North.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 6-10 cm. Brown, yellow to orange brown with fine velvety scales, usually dry unless found in wet weather.
mushrooms.pores: Mustard coloured but the ends on the outside are a darker orange/brown. Can blue where handled.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-10 cm long, 1.5-2 cm diameter. Concolorous with the cap but usually slightly lighter, cylindrical but sometimes with a slightly swollen base.
mushrooms.habitat: Yellowish bruising blue in the cap.
mushrooms.confusion: Grows in coniferous woodland (on acidic heathlands, moorlands or plantations), mycorrhizal with Pines, particularly Scots Pine.
mushrooms.taste: Larch Bolete (Suillus grevillei), pictured, looks similar and grows in a similar habitat but it has a ring zone on the stem that is absent on the Velvet Bolete.
mushrooms.facts: Yellow brown. Subfusiform.

mushrooms.name: Bitter Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-10 cm. Pale to dark brown. Starting convex with a suede like covering but flattening out, losing any small hairs and sometimes splitting with age.
mushrooms.pores: Starts with white, sponge like pores that develop a pink tinge around the pore openings and will bruise pink when damaged eventually turning brown.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-10 cm long, 2-3 cm diameter. Off white to tan with a darker net like pattern or reticulation, particularly towards the top of the stem. The base is usually wider than the top.
mushrooms.habitat: White and unchanging sometimes with a pink flush.
mushrooms.confusion: Mixed woodland, more often with broadleaf trees but will grow with coniferous trees.
mushrooms.taste: Can look very like a Penny Bun (Boletus edulis), pictured, or Summer Bolete (Boletus reticulatus) but the reticulation on the stem is dark on a lighter background for the Bitter Bolete and light on a slightly darker background for the Penny Bun and Summer Bolete and the pores of the Penny Bun and Summer Bolete do not bruise to a pink colour like the Bitter Bolete.
mushrooms.facts: Felleus roughly translates as bile which is a good description of this mushrooms bitterness.

mushrooms.name: Red Cracking Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-9 cm. A dull smooth brown cap when young then cracking to show pale yellow/buff underneath with hints of red. Where slugs have eaten the cap, which they often do, the damage shows red.
mushrooms.pores: Angular yellow pores that can green slightly with age. Bruises greenish. Xerocomoid Boletes have pore tubes that will generally split in half if the cap is torn apart, other Boletes pore tubes will normally separate and remain whole leaving them unbroken.
mushrooms.flesh: 5-9 cm long, 1-1.5 cm diameter. Buff to yellow with red fibres overlaid especially from the middle to the base.
mushrooms.habitat: White to cream in the cap with slight blueing above the pores after a couple of minutes, more red in the stem especially towards the base.
mushrooms.confusion: Under broad leaved trees.
mushrooms.taste: Being a relatively small Bolete with the cracking top and red showing through with damage it is hard to confuse this fungi apart from with other Xerocomoid Boletes. All are edible. Xerocomoid Boletes have pore tubes that will generally split in half if the cap is torn apart, other Boletes pore tubes will normally separate and remain whole leaving them unbroken.
mushrooms.facts: Common.

mushrooms.name: Sepia Bolete
mushrooms.description: A rather unspectacular Bolete that can be difficult to identify to species, particularly as it ages. Although edible, this mushroom is rather tasteless and has a very spongy texture.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-9 cm. Starts olive brown and covered in tiny velvet like hairs, becoming paler and cracking, revealing cream to pale yellow flesh.
mushrooms.pores: The pores are angular and start lemon yellow but darken with age and can then bruise blue. Xerocomoid Boletes have pore tubes that will generally split in half if the cap is torn apart, other Boletes pore tubes will normally separate and remain whole leaving them unbroken.
mushrooms.flesh: 6-10 cm long, 1-2.5 cm diameter. The top of the stem is bright yellow with a red zone surrounding the stem near the apex becoming brown/grey lower down, as the mushroom ages it looses these features with the stem becoming grey/brown with a slightly lighter apex.
mushrooms.habitat: White/yellow in the cap and top of the stem, becoming red/brown towards the base. Can stain blue when cut, especially in the cap.
mushrooms.confusion: In mixed deciduous woods and hedgerows, more often with Oak.
mushrooms.taste: Red Cracking Bolete (Xerocomellus chrysenteron), pictured, can look very similar but it usually has a mainly red stem and pink to red flesh between the cracks in the cap.
mushrooms.facts: Although edible, it is not a tasty mushroom and we don't recommend eating them.

mushrooms.name: Suede Bolete
mushrooms.description: A non distinctive, often hard to identify member of the Xerocomus genus that can be quite variable in colour.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 5-10 cm. Starting convex and then flattening out. Very variable in colour from dark brown to tan to olivaceous to yellow and even red. The surface is finely hairy (tomentose) or smooth as it ages and can crack, revealing a yellow or white flesh.
mushrooms.pores: Angular, pale to bright yellow and slightly running down the stem (decurrent). Can turn blue where bruised. Xerocomoid Boletes have pore tubes that will generally split in half if the cap is torn apart, other Boletes pore tubes will normally separate and remain whole leaving them unbroken.
mushrooms.flesh: 5-10 cm long, 1-2 cm diameter. Can be cylindrical, tapered or club shaped. Usually pale yellow with a pink/brown base and can have course reticulation at the apex. Can look fibrous with tiny floccules.
mushrooms.habitat: White to pale yellowish, sometimes blueing slightly in the cap but not always. The base of the stem is pinkish brown.
mushrooms.confusion: Associated with broadleaf trees but can be found with coniferous trees.
mushrooms.taste:
Rusty Bolete (Xerocomus ferrugineus) is very similar but lacks the pinkish brown in the stem base and has whiter flesh.
Poplar Bolete (Xerocomus silwoodensis) is again similar but has a more pronounced recticulum and grows with Poplar.
Goldenthread Bolete (Xerocomus chrysonemus) has wider pores and yellow hyphal cords joined to the base.
mushrooms.facts: Olive brown. Subfusiform to ellipsoid.

mushrooms.name: Bronze Bolete
mushrooms.description: Fairly rare but a great find. It is almost impossible to distinguish the taste and texture of this mushroom compared to the Penny Bun (Boletus edulis).
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-15 cm, usually dark brown to slightly red-brown. The caps starts a bit velvety and orange coloured but soon becomes smooth, dark and can have a finely cracked surface.
mushrooms.pores: The sponge like pores start white to cream and mature to yellow. The pores do not change colour much when bruised or handled.
mushrooms.flesh: 7-15 cm long, 2-4 cm diameter. Fairly robust and barrel shaped with a very fine brown mesh like pattern (reticulation) over a lighter brown background and can sometimes be slightly pinkish towards the middle of the stem.
mushrooms.habitat: Firm, white and unchanging when cut.
mushrooms.confusion: Ectomycorrhizal with various broad leaf trees, particularly Beech and Oak.
mushrooms.taste:
Summer Bolete (Boletus reticulatus), pictured, has a slightly velvety, pale brown to brown yellow cap. Its reticulation is paler than the stem, but still rather brownish.
Penny Bun (Boletus edulis) has a shiny, greasy cap, often with white margin. Its stem is pale, and the reticulation is white at the apex of the stem.
Pine Bolete (Boletus pinophilus) has a more red, shiny, greasy cap, often with paler (whitish) margin. Its reticulation is white at the apex of the stem, more brownish close to the base.
Bay Bolete (Imleria badia) has a thinner, unmeshed stem but as this is a good edible it is not a bad mistake to make.
mushrooms.facts: Rather rare in Britain.

mushrooms.name: Penny Bun
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-12 cm. White when very young, maturing to look like a crusty brown roll, hence the name penny bun. The edge of the cap is often white. Slug marks expose white flesh.
mushrooms.pores: Has very small white pores which can yellow a bit with age.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 2-4 cm diameter. Thick, bulbous and white ageing to slightly tan yellow. The stem has a fine net like covering just under the cap and sometimes extending all the way down the stem, solid when young, fresh or free from maggots.
mushrooms.habitat: White slightly yellowing with age.
mushrooms.confusion: Mixed woodland but found more with beech, oak or pine.
mushrooms.taste:
No poisonous mushrooms look similar, all the poisonous Boletus such as the Satans Boletus are either very red in the flesh or sponge, or stain blue immediately on cutting.
You could potentially confuse this mushroom with the Bitter Bolete, Tylopilus felleus which although not poisonous will ruin any meal you are unfortunate enough to add this mushroom to. A little nibble of the mushroom when raw will soon identify it with the Penny Bun being delicious and the Bitter Bolete being as bitter as sin! A better way to distinguish the two is that the Penny Bun has a lighter net like mesh on a slightly darker stem, the Bitter Bolete has a darker mesh on a lighter stem, pictured.
The Summer Bolete, Boletus reticulatus, looks very similar but has a slightly darker stem, not as solid flesh, lacks the white cap edge and grows in early Summer.
mushrooms.facts: Fairly common if you know where to look.

mushrooms.name: Pine Bolete
mushrooms.description: A great tasting mushroom that looks and tastes like the Penny Bun, the slight differences are the cap being red/brown instead of dark brown and the off white, slightly red stem.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-12 cm. White when very young turning dark grey/brown until becoming mainly red with maturity. It is usually more red than brown which can be the only way to differentiate it from the Penny Bun.
mushrooms.pores: Has tiny white pores which will yellow with age.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 4-7 cm diameter. The stem can be tapering, parallel or barrel shaped but is always quite stout and is usually off white to slightly red/orange with white, mesh like reticulation.
mushrooms.habitat: White, firm flesh.
mushrooms.confusion: With pines but will grow with other coniferous trees. Mainly found in Scotland.
mushrooms.taste: The Penny Bun (Boletus edulis), pictured, or the Summer Bolete (Boletus reticulatus) both look very similar, the Pine Bolete has a more red cap than the dark brown of the Penny Bun or lighter grey/brown of the Summer Bolete.
mushrooms.facts: Not common apart from in Scotland.

mushrooms.name: Summer Bolete
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 7-12 cm. Starting slightly velvety becoming finely cracked. Pale brown to brown yellow.
mushrooms.pores: Has very small white pores which can yellow a bit with age.
mushrooms.flesh: 10-14 cm long, 2-5 cm diameter. Can have a barrel shaped or parallel off white stem overlaid with a mesh that is lighter towards the cap.
mushrooms.habitat: White slightly yellowing with age.
mushrooms.confusion: Mainly with Beech and Oak but can grow with other broad leaved trees.
mushrooms.taste:
No poisonous mushrooms look similar, all the poisonous Boletes such as the Devil's Bolete (Rubroboletus satanas) are either very red in the flesh or sponge, or stain blue immediately on cutting.
You could potentially confuse this mushroom with the Bitter Bolete (Tylopilus felleus), which although not poisonous will ruin any meal you are unfortunate enough to add this mushroom to. A little nibble of the mushroom when raw will soon identify it with the Summer Bolete being delicious and the Bitter Bolete being as bitter as sin! A better way to distinguish the two is that the Summer Bolete has a lighter net like mesh on a slightly darker stem, the Bitter Bolete has a darker mesh on a lighter stem, pictured.
Could be confused with a Penny Bun (Boletus edulis) but the Penny Bun usually has a whiter stem, a white border around the edge of the cap, firmer flesh and comes out in late Summer and Autumn.
mushrooms.facts: Occasional.

mushrooms.name: Oak Polypore
mushrooms.description: A very rare big size, annual polypore. One of the four species listed in Schedule 8. of Wildlife and Countryside Act (1981), so it is illegal to pick or even cut samples. Most of the photos are from Hungary, where it is also rare, but not protected! The photos taken by Matt Payne are from the UK, a lucky rare find.
mushrooms.fruitingBody: 10-30 cm across, shelf-like to slightly convex, fan-shaped, semicircular or rounded. Margin rounded and finely suede-like. Whitish at first, then yellowing, but turns brownish with age. Upper surface smooth, finely velvety when young, might be cracking with age.
mushrooms.pores: Tubes up to 4 mm long, white, pores circular, 2-4 per mm, pore surface is white when young, then off-white to buff, bruising brownish when damaged.
mushrooms.flesh: Up to 4 cm thick, soft or corky. Whitish, once cut bruising reddish first, then slowly turns brownish.
mushrooms.habitat: Often on barkless hulks, fallen bigger branches or cutting surface of Oak trunks. Saprotrophic on weak, old Oaks (some authors wrote it is parasitic on Oaks), causing brown-rot on its heartwood. Growing solitary or in small groups of 2-3 fruit bodies.
mushrooms.confusion:
Birch Polypore (Fomitopsis betulina), pictured, grows on Birch only, and its flesh remains white.
Beefsteak Fungus (Fistulina hepatica) has red flesh with white veins and can often be found bleeding, while Oak Polypore has whitish flesh which turns reddish first then slowly to brownish.
Oak Bracket (Pseudoinonotus dryadeus) is mostly much tougher. Growing at the base of old Oak trees, on oak stumps or on the ground attached to buried roots. Often can be seen some dried amber coloured droplets on its margin.
Chicken of the Woods (Laetiporus sulphureus) is bright yellow everywhere, including its flesh.
mushrooms.taste: Spore print is whitish. Spores cylindrical to spindle-shaped, curved slightly at base, smooth and colourless (hyaline).
mushrooms.facts:
The scientific name changed recently to Fomitopsis pulvina, but apart from mycologists, nobody uses it just yet, so we decided to leave the scientific name as it was before, until the new name became more well-known.
This change is supported by DNA-evidence, and the relevant publication is:
